Providence: The Rhode Island Foundation has awarded another $450,000 in grants to several more nonprofits that are helping state residents cope with and recover from the pandemic. Centro de Innovacion Mujer Latina, Rhode Island Rescue Ministries and The Samaritans of Rhode Island are among the organizations that benefited from the latest round of grants. Centro received $30,000 to provide community mental health services and other assistance to the Spanish-speaking community. Rescue Ministries received $20,000 to purchase cold storage and nonperishable food containers for its homeless shelter, food pantry and soup kitchen. Samaritans received $20,000 to improve the responsiveness of its digital suicide prevention services. The foundation has now awarded more than $21 million in pandemic relief since March 2020.

South Carolina

Columbia: A federal judge suspended South Carolina from enforcing a rule that banned school districts from requiring masks for students. Parents of disabled children, helped by the American Civil Liberties Union, sued the state saying the ban discriminated against medically vulnerable students by keeping them out of public schools as the COVID-19 pandemic continues. The mask ban has been forcefully backed by Republican Gov. Henry McMaster and GOP lawmakers who said parents should decide whether students wear masks, not school officials. U.S. District Judge Mary Geiger Lewis compared the General Assembly preventing mask requirements to telling schools they can no longer install wheelchair ramps. McMaster’s spokesman, Brian Symmes, said the ruling isn’t the last word in the case. “The governor strongly disagrees with the court’s decision and will defend a parent’s right to decide what’s best for their children up to the United States Supreme Court, if necessary,” Symmes said in a statement,

South Dakota

Black Hawk: More than 150 homeowners in a development outside Rapid City are suing Meade County over risks to their properties after a sinkhole exposed an abandoned gypsum mine. The federal complaint filed Monday by Hideaway Hills residents in Black Hawk seeks damages to be determined by a jury and other relief “allowed by law or equity.” The sinkhole forced about 40 residents from 15 homes in April 2020. Geotechnical studies showed there could be water flowing through the abandoned mine and toward Interstate 90 and there is the potential for future sinkholes, the Rapid City Journal reported. The complaint alleged several violations of the state Constitution. It said the decision to approve the subdivision by the county Planning Commission and the Meade County Commission put homeowners at risk. Developers allegedly informed the county in 2001 of an underground gypsum mine and discussed taking steps to determine if it was safe to build on. The commission approved the subdivision proposal in 2003. Katelyn Cook, an attorney for the county, said her legal team does not comment on pending litigation.

Tennessee

Franklin:A house in downtown Franklin that belonged to the grandparents of country comedy legend Minnie Pearl, who performed at the Grand Ole Opry for more than 50 years, is for sale for $2.75 million. The home on West Main Street is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. It belonged to Ophelia and William House,the grandparents of Sarah Colley Cannon, better known by her stage name of Minnie Pearl. The Queen Anne-style home was built in 1873 and sits in Franklin’s historic downtown district. Many of the original furnishings and fixtures remain, including mantels for the six fireplaces. The distinctive home has glass doorknobs and intricately designed door handles. The nearly 6,000 square foot residence sits on a little more than an acre, and has four bedrooms and five bathrooms. Outdoor space includes a wraparound front porch, sunroom, back porch and patio. Hardwood floors are throughout the home.

Texas

Huntsville: Rick Rhoades, 57, was executed Tuesday night for fatally stabbing two Houston-area brothers during a robbery in their home more than 30 years ago. Rhoades was executed by lethal injection at the state penitentiary in Huntsville. He was condemned for the September 1991 killings of Charles Allen, 31, and Bradley Allen, 33. The brothers were killed less than a day after Rhoades had been released on parole after serving a sentence for burglary. Rhoades, strapped to the death chamber gurney, turned his head and looked briefly at relatives of his victims as they walked to a window in a witness area a few feet from him. Asked by the warden to make a final statement, he declined. He was pronounced dead at 6:29 p.m. CDT, 17 minutes after the lethal injection began. The U.S. Supreme Court declined to delay Rhoades’ execution over claims his constitutional right to due process was being violated because he was being prevented from pursuing allegations that some potential jurors at his trial might have been dismissed for racially discriminatory reasons. Rhoades was the third inmate put to death this year in Texas and the sixth in the U.S. Four more executions are scheduled for later this year in Texas, the nation’s busiest capital punishment state.

Utah

Moab: The police chief in the tourist town where officers stopped Gabby Petito and her boyfriend weeks before her death has taken a leave of absence. Moab Police Chief Bret Edge requested a leave of absence that began Monday, city spokesperson Lisa Church said. It is unknown if his request is related to criticism the department has faced over the past week after Petito’s body was discovered in a remote area in northwestern Wyoming. Petito and her boyfriend, Brian Laundrie, got into a physical altercation Aug. 12 in Moab that led to a police stop for a possible domestic violence case. Ultimately, police there decided to separate the quarreling couple for the night but no charges were filed and no serious injuries were reported. Last week, the city of Moab said it would conduct a formal investigation into the police department’s handling of the dispute. Petito was reported missing Sept. 11 by her parents after she didn’t respond to calls and texts for several days while she and Laundrie visited parks in the West. Petito’s death has been classified as homicide, meaning she was killed by another person, but medical examiners in Wyoming haven’t disclosed how she died pending further autopsy results.

Vermont

Montpelier: A food box program with its roots in the early days of the pandemic is ending after distributing tens of thousands of meals to people across Vermont. In June, the Full Plates Vermont program run by the Vermont Foodbank took over the Farmers to Families Food Box program that was begun by the U.S. Department of Agriculture. The original USDA program was designed to feed people left hungry by the pandemic and give those in the food industry, notably farmers, a place to sell their products. The food bank, working with private, state and other partners, coordinated food distribution events where people’s vehicles were loaded with boxes of food containing poultry, fruit, vegetables and dairy items. The Rutland Herald reported that after the original program ended in May, the Vermont Foodbank continued with its version of the program, which has distributed 40,000 meals since June. Sayles said after the program ends Thursday, people who benefited from it can check with the Foodbank to learn where they can get help.

Virginia

Richmond: Democrat Terry McAuliffe and Republican Glenn Youngkin clashed Tuesday night over vaccinations, tax policy, education and their respective records in the second and final debate in Virginia’s closely watched gubernatorial election. The event quickly got off to a combative start and neither candidate let up over the course of the hour, with each accusing the other of lying to voters. Five weeks from Election Day and with early voting already underway, recent polls suggested a tight race between McAuliffe, who is seeking a second term after his first ended in 2018, and Youngkin, a former business executive and political newcomer. Democrats made huge gains in Virginia while President Donald Trump was in office, taking full control of state government, but Republicans are more energized and optimistic about their chances this fall than they have been in years. The contest, one of only two regularly scheduled governor’s races this year, is also drawing national attention as a possible indicator of voter sentiment heading into next year’s midterms.

Washington

Renton: A woman has filed a lawsuit against King County Metro claiming a bus driver ran over her leg while she was laying on a sidewalk and then drove away. Jessica Chapel’s injuries were so severe that doctors had to amputate one of her legs, her attorneys said. The bus driver, who is no longer with King County Metro, is facing hit-and-run charges, KOMO-TV reported. Chapel was homeless in March and decided to lay down on the sidewalk to take a nap, her attorneys said. The bus pulled out of the South Renton Park & Ride lot and turned right, cutting the corner short. The rear tire of the bus ran on top of the curb and drove over Chapel’s leg, her attorneys said. “The injuries were gruesome,” said attorney Kirk Bernard. According to the complaint filed Tuesday, the King County bus driver initially stopped to check on Chapel before returning to the bus and pushing the response button to get help from law enforcement. The lawsuit alleged that the driver left Chapel on the road side and canceled the help that was supposed to be on the way. A passerby called for help.

West Virginia

Wheeling: A new program launched by West Virginia’s Supreme Court that uses technology to promote safety and access in cases involving sexual assault and domestic violence is expanding to Ohio County, officials said. The new system allows victims of domestic violence and sexual assault to file petitions for protective orders without going to a courthouse. Ohio County is the second community to pilot the program, which was introduced last month in Cabell County as a way to address safety concerns. The only option before the program was for victims to appear in person at the courthouse. “This new system will provide an option to victims to help keep them safe from the people they allege assaulted them. We also are ensuring every person’s constitutional rights are protected,” Chief Justice Evan Jenkins said.

Wisconsin

Wausau:The city could soon be home to up to 85 refugees, including some of the thousands of evacuees who fled the rise of the Taliban in Afghanistan. The Ethiopian Community Development Council announced Wednesday that it is preparing for the first 10 individuals to be resettled into the central Wisconsin city by December, and that another 75 could be received from January through September of 2022. The organization said among those resettled in the community could be Afghans, through the Afghan Placement and Assistance program. The organization received authorization for the resettlement from the Department of State’s Bureau of Population, Refugees and Migration, but no costs have yet been completed for the effort. Before the refugees can be resettled, the organization is working to hire a director for its Multicultural Community Center and raise funds to hire other local staff members, according to a release. As soon as staff members are in place, the group will work with local partners to prepare for the first arrivals.

Wyoming

Jackson: Widespread news coverage of Gabby Petito helped searchers in an unrelated case find a man’s body not far away, officials said. A team with a search dog looked for four hours Tuesday before finding the body of a man matching the description of Robert ‘Bob’ Lowery, according to a Teton County Search & Rescue statement. Lowery, 46, of Houston, went missing Aug. 20. The man’s body was found on a steep, wooded slope in the area of Teton Pass in western Wyoming. How the man died wasn’t immediately known. Authorities notified Lowery’s family while awaiting confirmation the body was his. News coverage of Petito, 22, who went missing on a cross-country road trip and whose body was found near Grand Teton National Park on Sept. 19, sometimes mentioned Lowery’s disappearance. That prompted at least two people to call authorities with information about Lowery, searchers said Tuesday. Lowery was wearing a black baseball cap with a gold letter “P” and spotted in hotel camera images carrying a black duffel bag with the Nike logo. Searchers in the area of a popular canyon trail said they found a bag matching that description with the body, far off the trail. The bag contained a tent and sleeping bag, Lowery’s sister, Leigh, told the Jackson Hole News & Guide. The Teton Pass-area canyon where the man’s body was found is about 45 miles from where Petito was found. Petito’s parents reported her missing Sept. 11 after she didn’t respond to calls and texts while she and boyfriend Brian Laundrie visited national parks in the West.

From USA TODAY Network and wire reports

search_result.title: Delaware to musician: Let there be rock in your backyard!
search_result.text:
The state of Delaware has one message to musician Butch Zito: Let there be rock ... in your backyard!

Last summer, Zito rushed to the Delaware Division of Arts office in Wilmington on the afternoon of the deadline to apply for one of the state's art grants.

A friend had pushed the veteran folk-rock musician to apply and on Christmas Eve, he got an email from the state announcing he was one of 17 fellows and was awarded with $6,000 toward his musical endeavors.

"It was a merry Christmas," says Zito, a New York transplant who moved to Delaware 30 years ago and performs with area acts like Stackabones and The Porch Chops. "Last year, I found out that Santa Claus really is around."

The bulk of the funds have gone into the backyard of Zito's 114-year-old Newport-area home where he has built a 15-by-20 outdoor wooden stage with a pergola where he will host a panoply of musicians for about six shows a year.

Zito, an architect, enlisted help from a group of 10 friends, family members and fellow musicians in the spring to help build the stage. And to to help christen the still-unnamed stage, he had a party a month ago that included performances by the countrified Sin City Band, jazz five-piece Kombu Combo, hurdy gurdy-playing Michele McCann Band and another of Zito's bands, Railroad Pete, which includes Montana Wildaxe's Tony Cappella.

He dubbed the show Chickenstock because there's an old chicken coop located close to the stage, near where his guests mingled and danced until midnight. The event was potluck and the green room was literally green – a patch of the lawn to the side of the stage.

Zito, 58, is now on a path to follow in the footsteps of the state's other house concert spots like the Cooldog Concert Series in Kenton, which has been going strong for 11 years, and the Terrapin Woods House Concerts in Newark, which started up in 2011.

None of the house concert locations in Delaware put on the shows to make a profit. It's a labor of love and the proceeds go back to the artists.

Bob Andrews knows all about house shows. The Illinois-based artist manager and co-founder of Undertow Music is not surprised that the number of spots hosting house concerts has been slowly growing in Delaware.

Undertow has helmed an expanding number of house concert tours for its national artists in the past five years – a total of 1,100 – and has become a national leader in the house concert bookings.

Singer/songwriters like Eef Barzelay (Clem Snide), Richard Buckner, Anders Parker, Damien Jurado, John Vanderslice and Will Johnson (Centro-Matic) have all done living room shows with Undertow, along with Philadelphia-based indie rockers Clap Your Hands Say Yeah.

David Bazan, the leader of indie rock band Pedro the Lion, has run with the concept, doing about 600 house shows since 2009 in up to 350 different towns across the country, Andrews says.

The reasons are simple: The shows are better and the artists make more money.

As an added bonus, merchandise sales are even higher at house shows with fans drawn in by the intimate experience, Andrews says. And with bands not making much money off record sales these days, more bands are on the road, making getting dates at venues more difficult to snag with an influx of acts on the road, he adds.

"When David began doing it, people realized it wasn't a consolation prize," Andrews says. "He did it because it's better than playing venues. He gets to keep all the ticket money, there's 50 or 60 people who want to be there and there's no talkers or bars to compete with."

For Zito, the metamorphosis from backyard to music venue now gives him and other musical acts that might not fit into the bar band scene a tranquil place to perform for ears that want to listen. In addition to an annual jam-themed Chickenstock each summer, Zito plans to host a singer/songwriter series, along with blues and bluegrass shows.

Zito hasn't hammered out an exact plan for how musical-lovers can get tickets for his shows, but he's leaning toward giving the performing bands an allotment of passes that will get their fans entry with a donation.

"I want to make sure everyone gets paid," Zito says. "Musicians are lower than a dishwasher on the pay scale, usually. I know how hard they work."

The annual Delaware Division of the Arts prizes range from $10,000 to $3,000. Only one $10,000 Masters Fellow prize is awarded each year and Wilmington photographer Carson Zullinger is the 2014 recipient. Zito, the only musician to receive the award this year, will join the other fellows at a ceremony Sept. 20 at the Biggs Museum of American Art in Dover and he will perform a pair of his songs.

Zito says he has had no complaints from his neighbors, who are invited to all shows. In fact, he says one neighbor trimmed his backyard bushes and built a fire pit so he could enjoy the music from his own property. Another stopped by for Chickenstock and by the end, he was so drawn to the setting that he asked Zito if he could get married in Zito's backyard with Zito's act as the wedding band.

While Zito focuses on booking local artists, Paul Gumerman's Cooldog Concert Series pulls in traveling acts from across the country, along with some international performers. Since Kent County doesn't have the size or scope of New Castle County's original music scene, Gumerman decided to import the music himself.

"There's really no place in this area to see the kind of music I bring in," he says, mentioning the Delmarva Folk Fest in Clayton as a rare explosion of original music in the area each year. "We're kind of out in the sticks."

His Celtic shows are the biggest sellers and he hosts everything from folk and rock to blues and singer/songwriters. He estimates about two-third of his crowd come from Delaware with the rest coming from bordering states. There's usually a $15-$20 suggested donation at the door.

Gumerman, who recently formed his own band called Key of Red, has held nearly 120 concerts in his Kenton home since 2003, which has both a permanent indoor and outdoor stage.

Music fans bring food for a potluck dinner and oftentimes the musicians stay the night at no charge.

Lodging for musicians is also part of the deal at Margaret Brown's Glasgow home when traveling musicians play the Terrapin Woods House Concerts.

The 55-year-old self-described "old Deadhead" started her series three years ago and has hosted about 20 shows. Unlike Gumerman's high-tech set-up, Brown's house concerts are a bit more old school. She doesn't even have a website to promote the shows, which cost $10-$20 in suggested donations.

"It's word-of-mouth. It's a true house concert. I don't have a sound system, even," she says. "This is not commercial. This is a private house. I tell people you're strangers when you come to my home and we are friends by the time you leave."

IF YOU GO

-- For updates on Butch Zito's backyard stage, go to his Facebook or ReverbNation pages.

-- Cooldog House Concert Series will host its next concert Aug. 10 at 4 p.m. with California-based Celtic rock group Tempest. There is a suggest donation of $15. (It's $12 for ages 10-18 and active military.) Go to here for more information.

-- Terrapin Woods House Concerts will have a concert by California-based, Celtic-inspired folk/rock act Sharon Knight on Thursday at 7:30 p.m. For more information, go here or call (302) 521-0632.

search_result.title: DELAWARE BACKSTORY: Flash back to 1970s' Newark
search_result.text:
robin brown

The News Journal

Whenever discussion of Delaware's past turns to music, two locations and three genres inevitably arise.

First mentioned, of course, are Wilmington and jazz.

Every June, the Clifford Brown Jazz Festival honors – as do a park, street and state historical marker – the hometown trumpeter who died too young at 25, but lives in legendary acclaim.

Second noted is Bob Marley, who lived with his mother, a longtime resident of Wilmington, while working at Newark's old Chrysler plant. As fans long for a state marker for that Delaware connection, he is honored each July in "The Annual Peoples' Festival 4 Peace Tribute to Bob Marley," founded by family friends.

Usually, the third genre raised is rock 'n' roll in Newark.

When Bruce Springsteen played The Stone Balloon. And George Thorogood and the Delaware Destroyers rocked The State Theatre and other hometown venues.

Neither marker nor festival honors that musical heyday.

In that time, all manner of rock bands, free-thinkers and newly minted Vietnam veterans were everywhere in the pot-smoky college town and its hinterlands.

Over the summer, however, the entire 1970s' Newark heritage had a most-fitting tribute.

That was one sunny September Saturday's celebration of a new book and old band.

The band was Snakegrinder and the Shredded Field Mice.

And the book, named from a song by that band, is "There's a House in the Land [Where A Band Can Take A Stand]." Subtitled "A Tale of the 1970s," it is a remarkably written bit of time-travel by award-winning journalist Shaun D. Mullen, a veteran of The News Journal.

A signing party reunited Snakegrinder for the first time in decadesat The Blue Crab in Suburban Plaza, Newark. David Bennett visited by Skype from The Philipines as Hangnail Philips aka Craig Smith sat in for him on keyboard.

George Wolkind and other band members said only Mullen could have caused "such a happening."

Snakegrinder was born as the house band of the book's setting – a commune-like farm where Mullen lived about a decade just over the line in Pennsylvania, a local legend for its fluid cast of characters, parties and goats.

Plans for the signing concert attracted so many reservations from survivors of the time, a second show/signing was added. The twice-packed total, said to have topped 500, drew with uncounted musicians and luminaries of the era, including Stone Balloon owner Bill Stevenson.

Newarkers of the era – especially rock fans, aging Deer Park townies and all who went to the farm – likely will find Mullen's thinly fictionalized memoir an engaging, funny and sometimes heartwrenching revisit to that time, inseparable from its place and musical score.

While Newark rock 'n' roll likely never will generate an annual celebration or historical marker – or the acclaim of Wilmington's Clifford Brown jazz or the Marley Connection – Mullen's book and its launch party were the next best thing.

Do you have a Delaware Backstory? Tell robin brown at (302) 324-2856, rbrown@delawareonline.com, on Facebook, via Twitter @rbrowndelaware or The News Journal, Box 15505, Wilmington, DE 19850.

HOLIDAY SPECIAL: Signed copies

Delaware Backstory readers and others in-the-know can get a signed copies of "There's a House in the Land [Where A Band Can Take A Stand]," subtitled "A Tale of the 1970s," by Shaun D. Mullen (Fishy Business Press, $12.95).

A special price of $12 each includes postage and souvenir postcard of the book signing/Snakegrinder Reunion featured in this column.

Orders must be placed by Dec. 15, quantities are limited.

The book also is available at the Ninth Street Book Shop in Wilmington and on Amazon, which offers a $9.99 Kindle version.

FOR MORE INFORMATION

search_result.title: Delaware nurse in Gretchen Emery Band turned hardship into new EP
search_result.text:
Gretchen Emery’s musical journey has taken the longtime nurse and soulful rock singer down a deep rabbit hole filled with unusual relationships and experiences that the Newark resident has cultivated over the last 20-plus years.

For evidence, witness The Gretchen Emery Band’s new EP, “If Love Were Enough.'' It’s a project she and her guitarist and husband Kenny Windle created that touches on themes of injustice, heartbreak and hope. The record was produced by Derek Chafin.The song “Addie” was inspired by the singer's heartache after she lost an infant patient nearly 30 years ago, while working as a pediatric nurse for a medical daycare in Delaware.

“I have cared for many children who have passed away, unfortunately. And he just touched me in a different way. Or he was the straw that broke the camel's back after losing a number of different kids,” Emery, 54, explained.

The song “Addie” is a fictitious name for the young patient’s grandmother. The music sounds a little like a marriage of rock and non-contemporary gospel, while Emery flexes her strong vocals on the tune. In the song, Emery asks Addie to tell her grandson — if she managed to find him in the afterlife — that she tried everything she could to save him.

“The music allows me a place to sort of … I don't want to say deal with the emotions, but it gives me a place to manage the feelings, some of which don't have words,” Emery observed.

The self-titled track, "If Love Were Enough," offers a laidback, hypotonic melody under Emery’s sassy, lounge-style vocals. As the song progresses, she turns up the pressure and morphs from casual singing into intense crooning, once again demonstrating her mighty chops.

The song features the chorus, “Love ain’t enough to keep the devil from knockin,’” which repeats a few times and ends with, “But I’ll be damned. Ain’t gonna give up on love.”

The title of the tune is a phrase that’s lived in the back of Emery’s mind for ages, she said. The singer explained she was inspired by a young terminally ill patient she cared for who was surrounded by a loving family, yet that love didn’t keep the child alive.

“If love were enough, maybe he wouldn't have to die. Maybe he would be OK. Maybe he could be healed," she said.

The music video for the song includes a social justice theme and features a wide range of people from different walks of life. It includes a biker with a George Floyd tribute on his vest, a gay couple sharing an intimate moment, and a young woman in a wheelchair armed with boxing gloves, among other subjects.

Cerebral palsy patient blessed her

Emery's best friend Lisa Carnley, of Middletown, is in love with the new EP. It moves her in a special way because her son, Cory, was Emery’s patient around the same time she was caring for the infant that inspired “Addie.”

Cory has special needs and was under Emery’s care when he was about age 2. He was diagnosed with cerebral palsy and has suffered seizures his whole life, according to his mom.

“His neurologist explained to me, he just doesn't have a very good brain. It's not one area of the brain that the seizures are coming from, it's kind of all over,” Carnley said.

When Carnley met Emery, it was at a traumatic time in her life. Her son wasn’t expected to live long and she didn’t know how to navigate through the healthcare system.

But Emery, who was just a stranger to her at the time, had her back.

“She helped get doctors to listen to me,” Carnley recalled.

Emery said Carnley has since become her No. 1 fan. “She’s at 99.9% percent of the gigs.”

Eventually, Carnley learned from another nurse that Emery was a singer. She came out to one of the artist's shows and was dazzled. “I saw her singing one time and was hooked. I just couldn't believe that voice came out of that little tiny body."

To this day, the singer still cares for Cory, who defied the odds and is now 27 years old. He's wheelchair bound, but he's got a strong will to live, his mama said.

“She's done so much for me just this past year, because I've had some vacations planned and she has come and stayed at my house and been his nurse while I was away,” Carnley said. “She's pretty incredible.”

Thanks to Emery's musical life, GEB's latest drummer, Tim Elliot, is now in a serious relationship with Carnley after the pair got acquainted at one of the band's shows.

"They met and it's all our fault," the singer said.

An ugly Volkswagen and an enviable gig

From 1989 to 2008, Emery worked primarily as a nurse. She’s since transitioned to a management role. When she’s off the clock, she kicks into singer mode.

Her husband Windle, 70, is semi-retired and works part-time restoring exotic vintage cars.

The couple has been married since 2012. But they first met around 1995 when they were both still married to other people.

The pair met when Windle came to Emery’s house to audition for her old cover band, the Condors. As Windle pulled up to her Newark home, the one they live in today, she was about to leave to run an errand.

Windle didn't make a great first impression.

“There is the most hideously colored green car in front of me. And I thought, ‘I hope to God that car is not coming to my house.’ Sure enough, it did. And it was Kenny.”

Windle didn’t join the band. But it had nothing to do with his beloved Volkswagen Golf.

A year later, the two randomly ran into each other at the supermarket. They discussed the idea of playing original music together in the band Red House.

Their partnership in that band went well and lasted a few years. One of their highlights was playing Warm Daddys in Philly, a venue that wasn’t any easy gig to land for local bands.

“That was a big deal back then,” Windle recalled. “But they loved us because we sold it out every time we played.”

'Rock ‘n Roll Honeymoon'

When Red House dissolved, Windle and Emery played in a few other projects together. They struck gold with their group Gretchen Emery & Dirty Boots, which lasted from about 2009 to 2014.

They earned a spot in the prestigious International Blues Challenge in Memphis in January 2013, competing against bands from all over the world.

Their run with Dirty Boots inspired their popular song “Rock ‘n Roll Honeymoon.” The tune was a nod to the fact that their competition in Memphis was basically the couple's wedding trip, after they tied the knot Thanksgiving weekend in 2012 and Emery went back to work that Monday.

“There's nothing we really enjoy more than playing music,” Emery said. “So we went down for the competition. That was kind of our honeymoon.”

In 2017, Emery and Windle began a new project and called it The Gretchen Emery Band. They ditched the “Dirty Boots” part because some people thought they were a country group. GEB has been going strong ever since.

From Christianity to 'the occult'

Emery was raised by teachers in a Christian home with a white picket fence in Dover.

Windle grew up poor in an extremely violent neighborhood in North Philly where books on Aleister Crowley, an occultist, magician and mountaineer, were read in his home. "My dad was deep into the occult," he recalled. The guitarist, who said he's not a religious man, lost his mom at a young age. His dad was a writer who retired as a publicist from Temple University.

A lot of Haitian immigrants lived in his neighborhood and they brought with them their religious traditions. “We had a voodoo witch that would go around and bless the block once or twice a month," Windle remembered.

The Philly native bounced in and out of the foster care system until he eventually landed back home with his dad.

Windle was a violent youth who was once sentenced to 23 months in a juvenile detention facility, he said, charged with being involved in the destruction of railroad property during burglaries.

“When he was doing his time, I was an infant,'' his wife joked. "I was just busting out [of the womb] and he was getting locked up.''

When Emery first met Windle, he was a more refined version of himself. And he was sober.

The frontwoman learned over the years that he was a genuine guy with a good heart, despite having grown up in a hellish environment. Her best friend Carnley has known Windle for ages and said he lights up around her wheelchair-bound son.

"Kenny loves Cory to death," she exclaimed.

Emery initially turned Windle down for a date once they were both divorced from their previous partners, because they had built a strong friendship that she didn't want to risk losing.

But her reluctance didn't last. "It turned out that we did not mess it up," Emery said.

These days, she and her husband are focused on making more music and playing gigs. Emery looks forward to what the next chapter of her musical life will bring.

She's been on a wild ride, both figuratively and literally.

That's because fate led her to sit in the driver's seat of her husband's ugly green Volkswagen Golf, the car she swore she wouldn't get caught dead in.

“My car was in the shop," she explained. "So I ended up driving that very car ⁠— eating my words."

The Gretchen Emery Band will play an acoustic set at Zollies (414 Delaware St., New Castle) from 7-10 p.m., Saturday. For more information, visit gretchenemery.com.

search_result.title: Live music returns: Delaware sees its first large-scale car concert
search_result.text:
Picture yourself in a car on a parking lot. With a tasty beverage and real, live music in the air.

That was the scene on Wilmington's Riverfront Friday evening as hundreds gathered for the state's first-ever large-scale car concert – a live performance of some of The Beatles' greatest hits.

"This man hasn't stepped out of the house in four months, but he came out here for The Beatles," said Sonali Pandit, pointing to her husband, Mohan, as he swayed to a rendition of the legendary British Pop group's "Yellow Submarine."

With the coronavirus pandemic halting large public gatherings – especially events like concerts, where people traditionally pack into crowded venue – this is what the new normal looks like for now.

Around 200 cars packed into a lot outside Frawley Stadium, spread in distanced rows with one or two parking spaces in between vehicles and all facing a stage where a local band jammed to The Beatles greatest hits.

Some sat listening to the performance on the radio in the cool of their air conditioned cars. Others sat on sunroofs, tailgates or in folding chairs outside their vehicles.

"I feel normal, well, as normal as it can get right now," said Maria Sawczak of New Castle.

She took in the concert in a red Mustang convertible with her girlfriends. They had made an evening out of it with dinner on the Riverfront nearby, something rare these days.

"It is just a joy," she said. "I feel it is something approaching normalcy."

Some swayed and danced in public for the first time in what they said felt like ages. Some gathered in small groups, but mostly people stayed apart.

"We liked the idea it was going to be safe," said Nette Stejskal of Pike Creek.

The 500 to 600 people that paid $25 a head to attend were treated to more than an hour of music by The Rock Orchestra, a Delaware-based band that plays tributes to different groups.

"The fact that I was playing to cars was the oddest thing," said Joe Trainor, the group's music director.

Instead of the crowd singing along and holding their lighters or phones aloft, those attending interacted with the musicians with a series of hi-beam flashes and horn honks.

With some people outside their cars, Trainor said the band was still able to hear the applause and interact face-to-face with the crowd. Like most musicians, it was the first time Trainor had performed in months. The emotion of that hit him, he said.

"To sit at that piano and play music with my friends, I just miss those people and I miss playing," he said. "It was a special night."

It is the first of what could be several such events hosted by the Grand Opera House, a Wilmington arts nonprofit that runs the namesake opera house on Market Street and other venues downtown.

Delaware is rocking again: Live music returns as stages begin to welcome customers back

"This is why we exist and we haven't been able to do it for a long time," said Mark Fields, executive director of the Grand Opera House.

The group also runs the Baby Grand venue and the Playhouse on Rodney Square downtown.

Fields said they've been working toward what they billed as "The Grand's Concert by Car" for about two months since it became clear the pandemic was not near an end.

Otherwise, they've ramped up their social media presence, rebroadcast old concerts and interviews, and introduced new programming to reflect the times, but the pandemic has been a challenge for the organization, Fields said.

"It is incredibly frustrating for a performing arts organization to not be able to perform," he said in an interview ahead of the concert.

Recent: New coronavirus cases continue to rise in Delaware, up 192 since Thursday

There was an awareness of that among the crowd. Some said they attended to get out of the house and help the organization along.

"This is supporting the area," said Chris Hesseck as he sat in a folding chair inside the bed of his pickup.

Like most arts and entertainment venues, the Grand has been hit hard financially by the pandemic.

Tickets, merchandise, concessions and rental fees account for some 65% to 70% of the organization's $7 million annual budget, Fields said. The rest is derived from contributions, he said.

Since the start of the pandemic, they've had to cancel 60 of their own events and about 40 rental events, he said.

Delaware is still in phase two of its reopening plan related to coronavirus. That means the Grand could technically operate at 60 percent capacity.

But with other social distancing requirements, that number limits attendance to about 350 people in Copeland Hall, the organization's 1,200-capacity venue inside the Grand Opera House.

"It's hard to do that economically," Fields said.

He said they hope to hold such concerts through the summer and potentially fall. Tickets for the next such concert, featuring a Pink Floyd tribute planned for July 17, will go on sale next week, he told the crowd at Friday's concert.

But even if the event becomes a fixture, it won't solve the money issue.

"It is a lot more expensive to put on a concert in a parking lot than it is one of our theaters," he said. "This is not something we are doing to make money."

Rather, he said the organization seeks to fulfill its mission to entertain and stay on people's minds.

Coronavirus: Taking a Delaware beach trip for the Fourth of July? Here's what you need to know

Given that packing people into rooms to take in live music will likely be one of the last pieces of normalcy to return, he said the organization's future is not entirely clear.

"Our fervent hope is people understand and appreciate the value of the Grand to the community economically, in terms of quality of life and artistic expression and make sure we are going to be alright in the long term," he said.

He said the Grand plans to survey those who came to improve on car concert setup.

Those attending said there is room to grow the concept.

Some, who were parked hundreds of yards from the stage, said the sound was fine, but wanted larger screens to see the band. The event also didn't feature refreshments for sale or restrooms, which Fields said is logistically difficult at this time.

"A bathroom would be good," said Juliana Forbes of Wilmington.

She watched the concert from the cab of her vehicle with Claude Forbes.

"It is different," Claude Forbes said. "But it is what we need to do right now."

search_result.title: Good news on horizon for Maryland and Delaware live music fans
search_result.text:
Roger Hillis

Special to The Daily Times

Things are slowly getting back to normal on Delmarva as business restrictions loosen — all because of the fact that COVID-19 numbers are falling. Restaurants and bars are gearing up for summer, and many of them are already presenting copious amounts of live music.

In Ocean City, this is the first week of 2021 that Seacrets has been open and featured live entertainment each day — and that’s the way things are set to remain there.

At 5 p.m. Friday, May 14, the Jim Long Band will kick off the first of its weekly happy-hour shows at Seacrets. These weekend kickoffs will no doubt please many regulars. as Long and company have been the house band there in the summertime since the ’90’s. Another rock act that will kick off a weekly residency is Go, Go Gadget, which will play at 10 p.m. each Thursday beginning May 20.

National touring comedian Rich Vos will perform a pair of sold-out shows at Seacrets on Tuesday and Wednesday, May 18-19. Those who were lucky enough to purchase tickets by phone or online when they went on sale may pick them up at will-call before the show (with first come, first served seating); you must be checked in by 8:30 p.m. or your table will be forfeited.

The Bottle & Cork nightclub in Dewey Beach was the place to be this past Monday, when country superstar (and Milton native) Jimmy Allen played a last-minute popup show for a good cause. Tickets were $10 at the door, and the line stretched down to the bay on Bellvue Street to enter the solo acoustic performance.

All proceeds benefited the family of Delmar police Cpl. Keith Heacook, who was tragically killed in the line of duty last month. Plans are afoot for additional fundraising events to be announced.

Allen had originally been scheduled to play a sold-out show with his full backing band at last weekend’s Springfest in Ocean City, but tickets were refunded as all of the national concerts under the big tent were canceled due to social-distancing concerns. However, dozens of local musicians played outside this year during the scaled-back event.

A fundraiser for a different recipient is scheduled for noon to 6 p.m. Sunday, May 16, at Hudson Fields in Milton. Gather and Give for Gavin is an outdoor festival to raise monety to assist Cape Henlopen High School student Gavin Birl, who was paralyzed from the neck down in a snowboarding accident earlier this year.

The music lineup consists of The Funsters, Lower Case Blues, Love Seed Mama Jump, Trent & the Trainwreck, Hope For Success and an acoustic performance by Electric Velvet. There will also be a petting zoo, yoga, food trucks and more. Tickets are $10 for adults and teens, with children under 12 being admitted for free.

Another upcoming music fundraiser in Delaware is one we previewed in this column last week. The semi-annual Hope Is Best event has taken place at Rehoboth- and Wilmington-area locations through the years, and raises awareness about mental health and the role it plays in suicides.

This year the concert will take place Saturday, May 15, and feature virtual performances online, with many of the acts broadcasting from Wilmington’s Theatre Nemours. It will be streamed on Facebook via both the theater’s page and the Hope Is Best page, and donations will be accepted. The event honors local singer-songwriter Aric Pringle, who died in June 2011.

This year’s performers include Lyric Drive, Wheezing the Juice, Cliff Hillis, Tyler Greene, Gaper Delay, Ray Hunter from Desoto Rust and also The Acoustic Cameltones. All proceeds will benefit the Delaware chapter of NAMI (the National Alliance on Mental Illness).

Looking ahead a week, Delaware will follow Maryland’s lead from earlier this spring, and revert back to 100-percent capacities beginning Friday, May 21. Tables will be spaced three feet apart, instead of six feet apart, yet dancing will still not be permitted. Masks will continue to be required inside, as well as at outside events with crowds of more than 250 people, such as music festivals.

search_result.title: PnB Rock, Firefly Music Festival alum, dies at 30
search_result.text:
Philly rapper PnB Rock wanted fans to know the First State wasn’t just special because it lacked sales tax.

“I (*&%$) wit Delaware lol y'all got the Badd b-tches,” the rapper posted on Twitter on July 24, 2016.

PnB Rock, born Rakim Hasheem Allen, will never get a chance to tweet any other thoughts about the Small Wonder because he died Monday after being shot during a robbery at a Los Angeles restaurant.

The rapper was 30.

The Los Angeles Times reported the gunman who killed PnB at the Roscoe's House of Chicken & Waffles restaurant demanded jewelry and other valuables before getting into a struggle with the rapper and opening fire, Los Angeles Police Chief Michel Moore said Tuesday.

Since Rock's death, photos of him performing at Firefly Music Festival in 2018, in a yellow rooster T-shirt, are circulating all over the internet.

Firefly’s strongest lineup for rap acts was arguably in 2018, when artists Eminem, Kendrick Lamar, Lil Wayne and PnB Rock gigged in The Woodlands of Dover.

PnB lived up to his name that year and rocked thousands of screaming fans from the Backyard stage during a late evening set.

Firefly fan: 'Awfully sad news'

On the Firefly Music Festival Fan Page on Facebook, a fan announced the rapper’s tragic death Monday night. Another posted a short video of his Firefly performance.

“Went through my old videos, I was sitting back in the grass watching him perform. Awfully sad news,” one grieving fan wrote.

“Over some jewelry ... So sad!” an angry person commented.

Songs with Lil Wayne, Firefly alum

Beyond performing in The Woodlands, PnB Rock also recorded songs with a host of former Firefly artists.

This includes tunes with festival alumni Lil Wayne (“T-Shirt”), Diplo (“Swervin’”), Fetty Wap (“Spend the Night”), Roddy Ricch (“Evolved”) and Wiz Khalifa (“TTM”).

PnB Rock was praised in 2017 when he was featured as part of XXL magazine’s popular Freshman Class issue.

He made noise on his two studio albums, “Catch These Vibes” in 2017 and 2019’s “TrapStar Turnt PopStar,” which hit No. 1 on the Billboard rap chart and, signifying breakthrough mainstream success, No. 4 on the Billboard 200 album chart.

The release featured guest appearances from Migos’ Quavo, Diplo and Tory Lanez, while a subsequent deluxe version offered features from Lil Wayne and Roddy Ricch.

Rock and partner Stephanie Sibounheuang spent their Sunday attending a wedding together, according to posts on their Instagram stories.

He is survived by their 2-year-old daughter, Zuri, as well as daughter Milan from a previous relationship.

WIL

Radio Halo makes Logan House debut

Delaware music fans might remember Dave Hepner as the high-energy frontman for the since-disbanded Bombs Away, a short-lived, but memorable pop/punk band that grew out of Middletown area.

The four-piece performed everywhere from Kanhunavulle to Dewey Beach from 2004 to 2006 before pulling the plug following the death of a band member.

Last year, Hepner re-surfaced at clubs as the leader of a new cover band, Radio Halo, which has performed a handful of gigs so far, including a few shows at Bank Shots on U.S. 40 near Glasgow. With Hepner behind the mic, the band is rounded out by Chris Young (guitar), Scott Vari (bass) and Brandon Townsend (drums).

Now, the rock cover band is headed to Wilmington's Trolley Square for its debut at Kelly's Logan House (1701 Delaware Ave.) armed with hit songs from the past (Sublime, Weezer and Green Day) and current ear-turners by Bruno Mars, The Black Keys and Imagine Dragons, to name a few.

There is no cover and the music starts at 10 p.m. Saturday. Go to www. facebook.com/RadioHalo Band for details.

— Ryan Cormier

Winter Jam raises temps in Arden

Yes, it's cold out and warmer temperatures seem so very far away.

So why are the organizers of the Shady Grove Music Festival, which is held each spring in Arden, so busy this week?

The festival is spinning off a trimmed-down, cold-weather version, appropriately named Shady Grove Winter Jam, to be held tonight at Arden's Gild Hall (2126 The Highway) starting at 8.

Wilmington-based jam bands Xtra Alltra and Apex Watson will team up with the soulful, horn-fueled funk band Universal Funk Order, which is also based out of Wilmington.

All three bands performed at an after-show party at The Chelsea in Atlantic City during Phish's three-night run at the Boardwalk Hotel on Halloween weekend. That experience helped lead to the booking of this show in Arden, with an eye on keeping the party going.

Tickets cost $10 at the door.

— Ryan Cormier

Dancing spectacle at DuPont Theatre

Channel your two left feet into something useful from Tuesday through Jan. 26 when "Ballroom with a Twist 2" brings a frenzy of fringe, sequins and Rumba bass to the DuPont Theatre (1007 N. Market St.) in Wilmington.

Riding on the popularity of talent-based reality TV shows like "American Idol" and "So You Think You Can Dance?," the show features sizzling dance moves by professional dancers like Derek Hough, Cheryl Burke and Tony Dovolani. Choreographed by "Dancing With the Stars'" Emmy-nominated Louis van Amstel, the evening of dancing and singing highlights Samba, Waltz, Foxtrot Quickstep and Jive.

Tickets for afternoon and nighttime performances are $35 to $80 each and can be purchased at duppontheatre.com or by calling (302) 656-4401.

— Margie Fishman

Sunday funday in Dover with Joe Theismann



Football icon Joe Theismann and jazz virtuoso Miles Jaye – known to a wider audience as the cop from the Village People – are both on tap for appearances Sunday at the Fire & Ice Lounge in Dover Downs Hotel & Casino (1131 N. DuPont Highway) in Dover.

Fans can meet the former Washington Redskins quarterback-turned-sportscaster after an interview and Q-and-A with Anthony Gargano of Sport Talk Radio WIP. The interview runs from 1:30-2:30 p.m., at which time Theismann will sign autographs until the end of the AFC Championship Playoff game between the New England Patriots and Denver Broncos, which starts at 3.

After the game, the club turns to a jazz spot with the former Village People cop returning to his jazz roots for a performance at 9 p.m.

Jaye has enjoyed a long music career, including hit singles "Let's Start Love Over" and "I've Been a Fool For You."

Both events are free.

For more information, visit www.doverdowns.com.

— Sarika Jagtiani

Clutch draws hard rock fans to Wilmington



It's not every night that World Café Live at the Queen (500 N. Market St., Wilmington) has a hard rock band headlining its downstairs stage and even rarer for the show to sell out a week in advance.

But that's the case with Maryland-based Clutch and the band's show at the Queen tonight at 8.

The act has gained a loyal following by touring often during its 20-plus year career as Clutch jumped from small labels to Columbia Records before settling down and releasing its albums on its own label, Weathermaker Music. Last year, Clutch released its 10th studio album, "Earth Rocker."

Tickets, which had cost $25 to $28, are being sold by ticket brokers for up to $130 a pair.

KingSnake and Crobot are the opening acts.

— Ryan Cormier

search_result.title: Local bands boycott musicians tied to white nationalist
search_result.text:
Ryan Cormier

The News Journal

The appearance of two local musicians with a well-known white nationalist has spawned outrage among some in the Delaware music scene, with several bands refusing to play shows with them.

In 2013, the news magazine Vice followed white nationalist Matthew Heimbach, who at the time was a Towson University student who had formed the White Student Union group to "celebrate European heritage," according to the group's website.

Heimbach and five people reported by Vice to be members of the White Student Union are seen patrolling campus in the documentary-style report by Vice Media, a news site that now has its own weekly HBO program. The video has been viewed more than 885,000 times and Vice reported that they participated on the condition that only their first names be used.

Delaware-based bluegrass/folk singer Patrick "Paddy" Corcoran, and Sean Giffing, a member of the Cecil County, Maryland-based punk band Plague Bubonika, both appear in the video with Heimbach.

"For those who are not Towson students, it seems hard to fathom that every single day black predators prey upon the majority white Towson University student body," the group wrote on its website. "White Southern men have long been called to defend their communities when law enforcement and the state seem unwilling to protect our people."

In the video, they meet at a restaurant over beers and pretzel bites planning that night's patrol, running through a checklist, including making sure there are batteries in their flashlights. They are seen praying in a parking garage and then walk at night through campus, located in the suburbs of Baltimore.

At some point, they stop at the offices of the Black Student Union and ask people if they want to join the patrol. No one takes them up on the offer.

Heimbach, while being interviewed in a room with a Confederate Flag hanging in the background and a "The South will rise again" bumper sticker on his laptop, says he always carries a pistol. Vice reports that the group "allegedly now have 57 members."

Later in the video, he stands on the outskirts of an equality rally on campus where then-Towson University president Maravene Loeschke speaks in support: "A whole lot is going to be better because you're here today. ... I don't know that I have ever in my life been more proud."

White nationalism is on the rise in the United States, in part due to the presidential election season and the presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump, says Keegan Hankes, a research analyst for Southern Poverty Law Center, a Alabama-based nonprofit legal advocacy organization specializing in civil rights.

"The tenor of Trump's presidential campaign has really lit a fire with these guys," Hankes says. "In the last six months, I feel like they are all energized in a way that I have not previously seen."

While Giffing does not comment during the 21-minute film, Corcoran, who has performed at Wilmington venues like World Cafe Live at the Queen, Kelly's Logan House, Oddity Bar and 1984, makes his views clear in the video.

"America as an idea is hardly existing anymore. The original idea is not what it's supposed to be now, what we're living in," Corcoran says. "We're essentially heading toward a dissolution of the United States. But in a sense, that could be for the better because it may lead to a white ethno-state, which is ultimately what we want. We want a national, strong nation-state that's well-defended, but at peace with the world."

When the Vice reporter asks him what the criteria of citizenship would be for this ethno-state, he answered, "The criteria of citizenship would be based, I mean, I'm going to say it bluntly, it would be based on race. It would be based on white. Absolutely. One hundred percent."

Gayle Dillman, whose Gable Music Ventures has booked Corcoran at the Queen for its singer/songwriter night as recently as last year, says she did not know about his pro-white views.

"Any racist activity, as far as I'm concerned as a business owner, is unacceptable," she says. "I would question going forward whether we would want to be associated with that."

Representatives from World Cafe Live at the Queen, Kelly's Logan House, Oddity Bar and 1984 all said they did not know about Corcoran's views before hosting him and would not have him back.

The video gained attention locally when Steve Beighley, guitarist for the Newark punk band Worth, saw it and began to refuse to play shows that included Plague Bubonika or Giffing.

Since then, several other bands have joined the boycott in solidarity.

"We have this great scene that we have worked so hard to make inclusive and fun," Beighley said. "The whole DIY local music ethos is inclusion no matter what. If you like the music, come out."

In recent months, Plague Bubonika, which has also performed at Holly Oak's Bar XIII, Oddity Bar and 1984, has been kicked off of seven recent shows over the video, says Plague Bubonika singer Anthony Taylor.

The band went on an "indefinite hiatus" earlier this week because of the controversy, Taylor says.

When contacted by The News Journal, Giffing gave a full-throated apology for appearing in the video, condemning the views held by those seen in the report. Giffing says he has never held those views and called his participation with Heimbach and the group a terrible mistake, adding, "Mistake is an understatement."

STORY: Demonstrators to Markell - End racism in state government

STORY: Redskins name divides Conrad community

Even though Vice reported that Giffing was a member of the White Student Union, he says that was never the case.

Giffing says he regrets not taking a stand and refusing to participate. He also apologized for any hurt he caused, stopping at times while welling with emotion.

"That's not me. That's not the band. That's never been anything that we stood up for or want to be associated with. I have trouble putting it into words because it's a visceral thing. I feel like I'm going to throw up," he says. "It's heavy. It's a real stain.

"I feel bad because I'm sure it affected many people negatively. I'm sure that patrol bothered people and I feel really bad about that. And then later to see Baltimore with such a problem with racism and the police department – I don't want to feel like I had anything to do with that."

As for Corcoran, who performs under the name Paddy Cardigan and Paddy Corcoran, he declined to comment when contacted.

"I don't have anything to say. I already know what this story is going," says Corcoran, who has also played with bands Paddy and the Brandywine Travelers and the Scrapple Creek Runners. "It's going to be biased as hell. I'm not stupid. I've been through it before."

Since the Vice report, Heimbach has since formed the Traditionalist Youth Network, which is listed as a hate group by the Anti-Defamation League and Southern Poverty Law Center.

Both have been tracking Heimbach since 2011.

In March, Heimbach resurfaced in the news when he pushed a female Black Lives Matter protester at a Donald Trump rally in Louisville, Kentucky. An April profile of Heimbach in The Washington Post followed the incident and carried the headline, "This white nationalist who shoved a Trump protester may be the next David Duke."

Marilyn Mayo, research fellow in the ADL's Center on Extremism, says there are different types of white supremacists, including "intellectual racists," people who are educated and try to push their ideology through publications and other means. There are also the "hardcore racists" like neo-Nazis and skinheads who openly sport white supremacist tattoos.

"Matt Heimbach is someone who bridges the gap between those two groups," Mayo says. "He is someone who tries to take an intellectual approach to white supremacy and is also trying to reach out to neo-Nazis and racist skinheads and build alliances with them."

Giffing says he rode in a car to Towson University with two friends, one of whom was female, after hearing they were planning to patrol campus primarily because he was worried for their safety. He says he thought they would be "trolling" people on campus as a statement of free speech – not starring in a Vice video about the pro-white group.

"Even though I didn't agree with the stuff they were saying even prior to us going there, I thought it would be a bad friend move to just let them go down and not do anything to keep my friends safe in a situation that could be dangerous and harmful," he says. "I wasn't there to be in it."

While he knew a Vice reporter would be there, he says he was surprised by Vice's cameras and tried to stand next to the cameraman as much as possible to avoid being in the video. He is only seen in the video a few times and does not speak. "I felt kind of blindsided," Giffing says.

Taylor, Plague Bubonika's frontman, calls the video "disgusting" and the band has posted a statement on its Facebook page that reads in part, "We never, ever, ever, ever, have been aligned with any of the views expressed in that video."

Adds Taylor: "We don't have any affiliation with any clan, clique, squad, group, club or union. We are Plague Bubonika and we stand for one thing: making music and having fun."

While Beighley and Worth have repeatedly refused to play with Plague Bubonika, he said he would change his mind if Giffing disavowed involvement with the group and denounced their views.

"I'd be proud to share a stage with them if they say, 'Hey, it looks like we're associated with this, we don't stand for this,' and actually confront it and turn it into a positive," he says. "That's what this is all about. People can change. You did a bad thing, you own up to it and make it a good message."

Contact Ryan Cormier of The News Journal at rcormier@delawareonline.com or (302) 324-2863. Follow him on Facebook (@ryancormier), Twitter (@ryancormier) and Instagram (@ryancormier).

search_result.title: Thorogood (finally) rocks Kent County
search_result.text:
Ryan Cormier

The News Journal

When it was announced in March that George Thorogood and the Destroyers would perform at the Delaware State Fair this summer, the 66-year-old Wilmington native had a bit of a confession to make.

"I never even knew you had a state fair," he told The News Journal at the time.

But after Friday night's downstate homecoming of sorts, it's doubtful that Lonesome George will ever again forget about Harrington's annual fair, in its 97th year.

"Harrington, Delaware – the world's best-kept secret. It only took us 40 years to get here, so we're going to take in every second of it," Thorogood announced at the Grandstand, possibly to help take the sting out of the fact that it was his first-ever show in Kent or Sussex County. "We have never had the opportunity to play the Delaware State Fair before and we hope the is the start of a long, beautiful relationship."

The Brandywine High School graduate's younger years in Delaware weren't always smooth, he has said in the past, recalling times when he was bullied for having long hair. So when he dug deep into his catalog for his 1993 cover of "Get a Haircut," it was payback time if one of those bullies happened to be in the crowd.

The ever-rebellious Thorogood was going to take a victory lap on one of the state's biggest stages.

He smiled as he sang the song's crowning verse, "I hit the big time with my rock 'n' roll band/The future's brighter now than I'd ever planned/I'm 10 times richer than my big brother Bob/But he's got a haircut he's got a real job."

Thorogood and his musically muscular four-piece tore through a feel-good, saxophone-laced 90-minute set filled with his blues-based rock hits, which was peppered with Delaware references and shout-outs.

While his band dropped the word Delaware from their name years ago, it usually comes out of retirement when Thorogood plays a show in his home state and he did not disappoint this time around.

"I have good news. I found out today that the Delaware Destroyers' probation officers have allowed them out for 24 hours for this one engagement," he said. "However, I'll do everything in my power to get arrested tonight. If someone has to go to jail for rock 'n' roll, it might as well be me!"

STORY: Love Seed Mama Jump, Delaware's king of covers, turns 25

STORY: Diversity, upgrades mark 22nd annual People's Festival



The fans at the state fair's Grandstand seemed to forgive Thorogood for the four-decade wait, although empty chairs on the floor and in the rear track seating area might mean that not everyone was quite ready to come out for his downstate debut.



Still frisky after all these years, Thorogood strutted throughout his well-honed show, shaking his hips and flicking his tongue. Even though the week's oppressive heat had lifted, the humidity had not and Thorogood had to change his shirt offstage halfway through his show.



The night was filled with his best-known re-worked blues and country covers, including an 11-minute run through John Lee Hooker's "One Bourbon One Scotch One Beer," Hank Williams' "Move it on Over" and the night's encore, "Madison Blues" by Elmore James. During Bo Diddley's "Who Do You Love?", Thorogood slipped in, "My times in Delaware can't be beat."

Thorogood also had some tricks up his sleeve, delivering a rare version of The Sonics' "Shot Down," along with "Tail Dragger" by Howlin' Wolf, which was transformed into a trademark Thorogood rocker.

But it was his biggest hit, the Thorogood-penned original "Bad to the Bone," that had the crowd on their feet. And he was not about to let the moment pass without giving it a First State injection.

"I make a rich woman beg and I'll make a good woman steal," he sang. "I'll make an old woman blush and a Delaware girl squeal."

The 10-day festival closes Saturday and the blues rock will keep coming. The fair's craft beer festival will be headlined by Blues Traveler with Rehoboth Beach's Lower Case Blues opening.

2. Who Do You Love? (Bo Diddley)

3. Shot Down (The Sonics)

4. Night Time (The Strangeloves)

5. I Drink Alone

6. House Rent Blues / One Bourbon One Scotch One Beer (John Lee Hooker)

7. Get a Haircut

8. Gear Jammer

9. Move it on Over (Hank Williams)

10. Tail Dragger (Howlin' Wolf)

11. Bad to the Bone

12. Madison Blues (Elmore James )
