Nov. 28, Newark, investigated by the University of Delaware Police Department. Antisemitic. Unknown suspects joined a Mishelanu WhatsApp group and sent threatening messages to members.

Dec. 30, Laurel, investigated by Delaware State Police. Anti-Hispanic. Two suspects threatened to blow up a business and kill employees while yelling racial slurs over an incorrect food order.

A pledge to Speak Out Against Hate

Speak Out Against Hate is an offshoot of the Southern Delaware Alliance For Racial Justice. Their nonprofit status is pending, according to president Patty Maloney.

Co-founder Peter Schott explained why the group formed last year.

“There had been a few hate-related incidents and people started talking about how there was a failure to respond to them,” Schott said. “We’ve got to make sure elected and appointed officials respond when they hear these things.”

The hate-related incidents Schott was referring to include when, in 2020, "TRUMP" was burned into alliance founder Charlotte King's Lewes yard, likely with weed killer. Then there was the incident with Allan and Leslie Slan in Rehoboth, around Christmas 2022, in which someone strewed a newspaper across their lawn and neatly placed the obituary of a Jewish person, marked with the Star of David, next to a sign that said "Happy Hanukkah, Love and Light."

"We realized: This is happening here," Maloney said. "We're trying to make sure hate doesn't grow here, that people want to come here and feel safe."

Speak Out Against Hate has five action groups, including faith, businesses, police, youth and schools and elected officials, and the leaders of each group reported on their progress at January's meeting.

Related:Antisemitism almost quadrupled in Delaware last year. What it means for the First State

Nancy Clack leads the elected officials' action group and said their first order of business was to ask all Sussex County legislators and mayors to sign a pledge to speak out against hate.

The pledge states: "There is no place for hate in Sussex County or the State of Delaware. Therefore I (name, office, district or town) pledge to speak out against hate publicly and to support legislation that is designed to hold individuals and other entities who express hate accountable for acts defined as a hate crime."

After two rounds of attempts to contact Sussex's 25 mayors, five senators and nine of 10 representatives (Ruth Briggs King had announced her intent to vacate her seat and Valerie Jones Giltner had not yet been elected), only one person, Mayor John Collier of Milton, has signed the pledge.

"In my opinion, there is nothing radical about that statement," Clack said. "Signing this pledge is not a political opportunity. It's what's right to do."

Shannon Marvel McNaught reports on Sussex County and beyond. Reach her at smcnaught@gannett.com or on Twitter @MarvelMcNaught.

search_result.title: Delaware State Police see crime drop using 'hotspot' data mapping
search_result.text:
When Delaware State Police Trooper Christopher Garcia clocks in for his shift at Troop 4 in Georgetown, he has a good idea where he'll be needed most days.

Garcia usually finds himself patrolling the Long Neck/Oak Orchard area of Sussex County – a hotspot – making traffic stops, doing crime prevention checks, interacting with residents and generally making his presence known.

That high visibility in crime hotspots is the foundation of an evidence-based, data-driven policing model called State Police Enhanced Analytic Response that all nine of the DSP troops up and down the state are now using.

Since the latter part of 2016, DSP has been using crime data to assess where the most resources are needed. That's where additional resources are deployed.

STORY: Twenty years after Capano arrest, juror breaks silence

Superintendent of the Delaware State Police Col. Nathaniel McQueen Jr. believes the new practice will reduce crime, improve traffic safety and strengthen community partnerships by leveraging technology.

Up and down the state, McQueen has seen the model that holds Troop commanders and troopers alike accountable yield results.

"To date, the S.P.E.A.R. program is working effectively in all three counties," Col. McQueen said. "Future success of the S.P.E.A.R. program will require it to become institutionalized into the daily operations of the Delaware State Police, similar to answering 911 calls."

In Sussex County, Oak Orchard is a target, where crime had been on the rise the better part of the last decade until DSP initiated the S.P.E.A.R. model there.

Crime drivers in that area are burglaries, thefts and robberies, most of which are tied to drugs. DSP looked at data the past three years and found an inordinate amount of these crimes occurring, with the majority being burglaries and thefts from vehicles in the Oak Orchard area.

Trooper Garcia believes his presence in that hotspot and the community outreach efforts made by himself and other troopers has paid dividends in this community nestled against the Indian River.

"Because we have had more of a police presence in this area, crime has gone down," said Garcia, the Delaware State Police 2016 Trooper of the Year. "Not only have we successfully targeted certain crimes in certain areas, we've gained the community's trust."

The crime stats tell a similar story.

Since 2015, complaints in Oak Orchard have been reduced almost in half, from 2,491 complaints in 2015 to 1,508 in 2016 and then 1,225 year-to-date in 2017.

There were 2,276 criminal incidents reported in Oak Orchard since Jan. 1, 2015, of which 57 percent were mainly non-criminal offenses (disorderly conduct, family offense, trespassing, local fugitive, sudden death investigations).

A quarter (25 percent) of the Oak Orchard criminal incidents were core crimes (aggravated assault, burglary, drug offense, homicide, robbery, rape, shoplifting, theft and vehicle theft).

STORY: S.P.E.A.R. model reduces crime in Dover's Alder Park

STORY: Middletown looks for money to attract downtown investors

Since the inception of S.P.E.A.R., the Oak Orchard area has experienced a 12.8 percent decrease in the number of incidents involving core crimes in the first nine months of 2016 compared to the first nine months of 2015. Data from January-September in 2017 showed that lower level of core crime incidents continuing.

"When we started S.P.E.A.R., we were handling as a troop about 200 complaints a month in Oak Orchard, which included everything from a domestic, shoplifting, theft, burglary, we were handling it," said Troop 4 Commander Capt. Rodney Layfield. "When we started S.P.E.A.R. ... within about a year, and it has continued since, we have almost cut crime in half down there."

Layfield said that because his troopers are now aggressively targeting that area, they are also reporting more criminal complaints, which in turn continues to reduce the level of crime and makes the success even greater.

While it has been a progressive downturn, Layfield said there are still spikes in the summer months. He said that happens more in Long Neck, but Oak Orchard has a summer population that comes down from other areas which he says increases the workload and crime across the board.

"We have a larger population, which means the crime complaints you handle will go up," he said. "We've seen great success in targeting Oak Orchard in this manner. We have a large percentage of our crime committed by a small percentage of the public and we are able to target these people."

Layfield said the success has come from having troopers in the right area at the right time. He said that there are different shifts held accountable, but in the big picture of the Troop, the hotspot areas are saturated about four hours a day.

"We don't want every trooper in Oak Orchard 24/7 because it's a hotspot," he said. "We'll take one encumbered resource (trooper) and put them in the area for that specific time. We’re going to solve crimes by troopers taking the extra step. It's just smarter policing."

S.P.E.A.R. policing model

State Police Enhanced Analytic Response (S.P.E.A.R.) essentially says we are using evidence-based procedures to respond to crime and help solve those problems that are occurring in the communities, said Capt. William Crotty, the man in charge of implementing the program DSP-wide.

Crotty said the model uses hotspot analysis, which is date, time-of-day, day-of-week frequency for particular problems.

Core crime management also is used to determine the highest crimes in a certain hotspot and crimes that are most important to that community.

In addition, micro-time hotspots, or trends, are looked at to determine where to deploy DSP resources (troopers).

"These pillars become priorities for resources," Crotty said. "Commanders have to make sure they have enough resources in place to cover all the aspects. Our goal is to stop trends as early as possible."

Crotty likens hotspots to a similar data-driven model in professional baseball. He said it is a proven model in Delaware.

"If you are a fan of the movie 'Moneyball' it's like playing the shift in baseball," he said. "A question every day is are we patrolling the areas or communities that need it the most? And when we are in there, are we participating in behaviors that optimize solving the problem? That’s what we focus on."

Layfield sees the model work every day. He said in the past, he would have troopers come into work and if there was something pressing they would be given direction. But he said there was a percentage of the time where they would leave the Troop and decide then and there if they should go left or right.

Now, he said they are given a specific mission based on the data and the hotspots where they are needed.

"If they are in a certain sector, they know where to target," Layfield said.

The Troop 4 captain said that when his troopers respond to a car burglary scene, for example, they aren’t just asking an owner of that vehicle if they want the vehicle processed. That is no longer acceptable, he said. They are held accountable for doing more.

Layfield said troopers are processing vehicles and entering information into databases to search for different stolen items and to see if there are similarities to other break-ins.

"We want our troopers to do more than just show up and say you have a really nice car and you may not want dust thrown all over it to be processed because you just lost $1.50 in change," he said. "That used to be a good answer. But the process now is we’re going to dust your vehicle for prints because they might have taken a $1.50 from you, but three houses down they took a GPS, they took a lady’s pocketbook that has all of her credit cards and important information. So if they happen the same night, those fingerprints from your car might lead to the person who broke into the other cars as well."

Layfied said his troopers are doing more canvassing of crime areas and knocking on doors as well.

He said you’d be amazed at how helpful canvassing an area can be. For instance, somebody might just say he has a deer camera in his yard and maybe it picked something up that would help solve the crime. That just happened recently in Dagsboro.

"If troopers weren't canvassing, they wouldn't have gained that information that solved the crime," Layfield said.

Traffic hotspots, too

Layfield said that if you live in Sussex County, you've seen a trooper sitting at the cemetery between Millsboro and Georgetown on U.S. 13 because that stretch of the highway is a traffic hotspot.

It means there has been an inordinate number of accidents, so the DSP targets that area based on data and accident trends.

"We’ve helped correct it with DelDOT by putting a light at the speedway to try to diminish the number of accidents, but we also target that area," Layfield said. "When it is congested we have a lot of accidents."

Layfield said there is a specific time that troopers are out there and wherever he goes in Sussex County and asks people if they see troopers in that area, they all nod their heads because they know not to speed between Millsboro and Georgetown.

Another traffic hotspot is Route 24, east of Millsboro, which ties into Long Neck and Oak Orchard, Layfield said.

"So our criminal hotspot also has a little bit of a tie to our traffic hotspot," he said.

Right now, Layfield said there is a statewide goal to reduce traffic collisions, as well as clamping down on drunk driving.

"We have a DUI hotspot where we are having a lot of related accidents and we try to put troopers in that area to target DUIs with additional enforcement," he said.

Many of the accidents involve people who are under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Out of the 119 deaths in Delaware related to fatal crashes in 2016, 69 were operators of the vehicles. Out of those 69, 36 were under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Out of 36, 14 were under alcohol alone, while 17 had marijuana in their system.

"The most prevalent drug of all of the fatal operators was marijuana," Layfield said. "Intoxicated drivers from substance abuse is huge."

Community outreach

One of the final steps in the State Police Enhanced Analytic Response model is community outreach.

Trooper Garcia has made inroads in the Oak Orchard area by getting out of his vehicle and talking to residents and assuring them DSP is paying attention to crime in the area.

"I look to have a positive interaction with the community or outside of residences and that is building trust," he said. "I don't want to just drive by people. If they are out, I normally stop and engage with them."

Garcia said that recently, community resource officers and troopers are going out into the communities to attend events to strengthen that community tie.

It appears to be working.

Millie Charnick, vice president of operations of Boys and Girls Club of Delaware, said that the partnership with the Delaware State Police in the Oak Orchard area is helping the community gain trust and feel more comfortable with the police presence.

She said troopers often attend community events, volunteer as a judge for the club's Junior Youth of the Year event, provide fingerprinting opportunities, and also led a discussion recently about bullying prevention with the youth who attend the club.

DSP also has made special arrangements for the K-9 unit, helicopter, and the mounted unit to attend the Boys and Girls Club community days.

"The Delaware State Police are a great asset to the entire community because they are visible and understanding to issues," Charnick said.

Reach Jerry Smith at jsmith17@delawareonline.com. Follow him on Twitter at @JerrySmithTNJ.

search_result.title: 'It's a disturbing trend.' Cities see large increases in carjackings ...
search_result.text:
CNN —

Carjackings have risen dramatically over the past two years in some of America’s biggest cities.

Just outside Chicago, a state senator’s car and other valuables were taken at gunpoint in December, and a group of children, one just 10 years old, carjacked more than a dozen people. A rideshare driver being carjacked shot his attackers earlier this month in Philadelphia. Last March, a 12-year-old in Washington, DC was arrested and charged with four counts of armed carjacking.

“The majority of it is young joyriders. They’re not keeping the cars. They’re jacking cars to commit another crime, typically more serious robberies or shootings, or joyriding around for the sake of social media purpose and street cred,” said Christopher Herrmann, a professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. “It’s a disturbing trend.”

Comprehensive national data isn’t available because the FBI’s crime reporting system doesn’t track carjackings. But large cities that track the crime reported increases in 2020 and 2021, especially as the pandemic took hold of the country.

The number of carjackings quadrupled in New York City over the last four years, according to data released by the NYPD. The city recorded more than 500 carjackings in 2021, up from 328 in 2020, 132 in 2019, and 112 in 2018.

Carjackings in Philadelphia nearly quadrupled between 2015 and 2021, according to figures released by the city’s police department. They recorded more than 800 last year, up from about 170 in 2015.

In New Orleans, there were 281 carjackings last year, up from 105 in 2018, the earliest year of available data. The city has also seen a string of carjackings this year, with NOPD reporting 39 as of January 21.

More than 1,800 carjackings were reported in Chicago last year, the most of any large city, according to data released by police departments to CNN. Chicago’s 2021 tally was the most on record over the last 20 years. Carjackings had been steadily declining in the city after 2001, hitting a low of 303 in 2014, but began to tick upward before skyrocketing to 1,400 in 2020 following the onset of the pandemic. Last year saw more than five times as many carjackings as in 2014.

‘We recognize the fear and uncertainty’

“It is lawless,” said Raymond Lopez, an alderman for Chicago’s 15th Ward. “It doesn’t feel lawless. It is.”

Chicago’s clearance rate for carjackings is low, and has further declined during the pandemic. According to the University of Chicago’s Crime Lab, only 11% of carjacking offenses resulted in an arrest in 2020, down from 20% in 2019. Just 4.5% of offenses resulted in charges approved by the State Attorney’s Office.

Chicago, a city of 2.7 million people, recorded more than three times as many carjackings as New York, where the population is almost three times higher. Chicago police officials declined to comment.

Philadelphia police posted a message on Facebook telling residents they were prioritizing the solving of carjacking cases and that more officers had been dedicated to that task.

“We recognize the fear and uncertainty these incidents bring, as the victims in these cases have touched nearly every demographic,” the statement read. “The PPD has deployed additional resources to investigate these incidents and apprehend offenders.”

In December, Pennsylvania Rep. Mary Gay Scanlon (D) was carjacked at gunpoint in Philadelphia – a 19-year-old from Delaware was later arrested for the crime. News outlets in Philadelphia have reported more than 100 carjackings have already taken place so far this year.

There are problems tracking data

Many cities do not have data on carjackings readily available, as police departments will often categorize these crimes as robberies or assaults. It’s difficult to understand the scope of the problem at a national level because the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting program, which law enforcement agencies voluntarily submit their crime data to, does not track carjackings.

However, more agencies are beginning to track carjackings separately. Dallas began classifying these crimes separately from robberies in their data last year and reported 453 carjackings in 2021. The Metropolitan Police Department in DC last year created a task force dedicated to addressing carjacking and auto thefts. Reports of auto thefts are also up across the country and are more reliably tracked than carjackings.

Kim Smith, director of programs at University of Chicago’s Crime Lab, says that tracking crimes in greater detail is a key part of finding solutions.

“I do think it’s important to be as granular as possible when you’re collecting data on crime,” she told CNN. “Who are the victims? Where do things take place? A lot of carjackings are done with a gun. If we’re trying to address gun violence, then we need to be as granular as possible.”

More detailed reporting also makes it easier to spot trends and patterns – in its 2021 report, “How the pandemic is accelerating carjackings in Chicago,” the Crime Lab found that the majority of carjackings were concentrated in the south and west sides of the city, where gun violence is disproportionately high. The majority of the victims of carjackings were Black or Hispanic.

Smith says she hopes the detail provided in the Crime Lab report can encourage officials in other cities to take a closer look at the circumstances under which these crimes occur. “There’s a lot that surprised us in the analysis, and I do think some of this is a call to action,” she said.

Some ‘emboldened to be repeat offenders’

Shifting attitudes toward the juvenile justice system, and Covid-related restrictions aimed at reducing the number of people in county jails or juvenile facilities, has created a situation where accused criminals who’d normally be held in custody are free while awaiting trial, experts told CNN.

That’s created a “revolving door” situation where “some were emboldened to be repeat offenders,” said Jeffrey Norman, chief of the Milwaukee Police Department. “We saw this on a higher level in 2020 and 2021.”

In Chicago, Lopez said people arrested and sent home with electronic monitoring sometimes reoffend while awaiting trial for something they’ve been arrested for.

“It’s like the perfect storm, where all these soft on crime policies have come to a head during this pandemic,” he told CNN.

The Crime Lab’s study of Chicago’s carjackings found that almost half of all carjacking arrestees in Chicago in 2020 were under 18. Between 2019 and 2020, there was a 104% increase in the number of arrestees who were minors. For many of them, it was their first contact with the criminal justice system, according to Smith.

The increase in carjackings committed by minors underscores the extent to which the pandemic has impacted young people in America – especially in areas that were already struggling. The report states that carjackings occurred with more frequency in areas with poorer internet access and lower school attendance.

Smith noted that kids living in areas with lower internet access had fewer opportunities to engage in school, remote learning and program providers over the past two years. “The impact of the pandemic, I think, can’t be overstated,” she said.

Lopez said the choice to not take crime seriously among young teens will have consequences years later when they age out of the juvenile justice system.

“When you have carjackers who are 15 on their third car, that’s a problem,” he said.

Norman, the Milwaukee chief, said it would take a multi-faceted approach to begin addressing the rise in carjackings.

“You’re not going to police your way out of this,” Norman said. “Everyone has to share responsibility when it comes to kids.”

Norman said that the behavior of children in a community were like “canaries in a mine. When a community has issues, kids are falling to particular types of behaviors.

“This is my thing. When a child doesn’t love himself or herself, I worry about the community that has that child. That’s no holds barred behavior that child will be engaged in,” Norman said. “A hungry kid will do whatever it takes to put food in his stomach.”

The closure of schools and advent of remote learning, the stress within households related to that and economic insecurity, and the pandemic stress on other institutions have all contributed to teens having more free time and less stability in their lives.

“You don’t take care of basic things, you can’t get to self-realization,” Norman said. “Not every kid is out doing things to put food in their stomach. But there are things not being take care of – whether it’s having positive mentorship, or areas of socialization not (being) available.

“It’s sad seeing despair and the lack of resources any normal kid should have,” Norman said. “As the old saying goes, ‘Idle hands are the devil’s work.’”

search_result.title: Campaign launched to light up Dover's high-crime areas
search_result.text:
When Lamotte McCallister opened his front door to four people wearing fluorescent yellow shirts bearing the phrase "Lights-On Dover Strong," he didn't know what to expect.

When he heard why they were there, he was all in.

The volunteers were among a group going door to door providing residents in central Dover energy-efficient LED lights for their front porches and solar-powered LED motion-sensor floodlights for their backyards. It is part of an effort to reduce crime in an area that has historically seen the highest numbers.

Under the program, residents on 14 streets – including New, Queen, Kirkwood, Bradford and Governors streets – can get the free lights if they pledge to turn them on every night.

"The goal is to increase security and empower residents to increase public awareness of criminal activity in these high-risk areas," said Chanda Jackson, community engagement specialist for Restoring Central Dover. "Neighbors working together and talking to each other creates a sense of community. We hope it will demonstrate a unified community approach to public safety."

Volunteers from the HELP Initiative Inc. and the Restoring Central Dover, along with interns from Delaware State University, have been out all week installing the lightbulbs and motion floodlights on houses whose owners signed a pledge to reduce crime during a kickoff block party at the end of June.

STORY: Three state hospital workers charged after patient dies

STORY: Smyrna hires firm to investigate police chief

The boots-on-the-ground effort also approaches owners in houses that are not already signed up to try to get full neighborhood participation. McCallister fell into that category.

"This is amazing," said McCallister, who lives on South Queen Street. "I didn't know this was happening, but I think it might help deter people from going in backyards. I think this will help decrease crime in the area."

That's the hope of the Dover Police Department, a community partner in the campaign. Dover Police Chief Marvin Mailey Jr. believes the effort is a great prevention tool in some of the city's high-risk neighborhoods.

The area around South New Street, South Governors Avenue, South Bradford Street and South Kirkwood Street has seen more than its share of crime and is considered one of the worst areas in the city, he said.

Mailey said people there want to have a better quality of life.

"Typically, this is our high-crime area, and we are trying to change the landscape of the city," Mailey said. "This program will definitely make Dover safer. Our bad guys don't like to stand under lights when they commit crimes."

According to Dover police data, burglaries and robberies rose by double-digit percentages in 2016, as were violent crimes, including murder, rape, robbery and aggravated assault. A large number of those crimes are occurring in the campaign's target area, Mailey said.

When the campaign was first discussed publicly in April, the goal was to reach 200 homes in a 75-block area. That number is now 500 homes, according to Jackson. She estimates the cost for materials is $9,000, with the labor being donated by volunteers.

Jackson said a number of partners have pledged money and labor, including the HELP Initiative Inc., Delaware State University, NCALL Research Inc., Habitat for Humanity of New Castle County, Delaware Sustainable Energy Utility, the Home Depot and Dover police.

"This is a community effort and the residents seem pretty receptive. So far, we've had positive reaction to the campaign," she said. "We're getting calls from residents asking when they can get their bulbs. It's a matter of breaking the ice and building relationships."

Charlie Kistler and Harold Stafford have been providing the installation labor this past week and will continue their efforts until all the houses in the target area have bulbs and motion sensors. Along the way, the founders of the HELP Initiative Inc. have been educating homeowners about the campaign and also about energy efficiency in general.

"The residents commit to leaving the lights on and also to keeping their neighbors aware that it is important to keep their lights on, too," Kistler said. "When we go from house to block to neighborhood and then the city, we want to light it up to the point where we can reduce crime."

But the effort is about more than crime, Jackson said.

Restoring Central Dover was adopted in 2014 as a comprehensive neighborhood revitalization plan. Jackson said the plan represents the community’s vision for restoring the vitality of Central Dover and lists recommendations for implementation over the next 10 years.

Resident input and priorities have been derived from a community survey, meetings, events, activities and community outreach, she said.

"Lights-On Dover Strong is just a piece of the puzzle," she said. "Relationships are important in this campaign and all of our efforts. If we don't trust each other, nothing will change."

Reach Jerry Smith at jsmith17@delawareonline.com. Follow him on Twitter at @JerrySmithTNJ.
